docs.title: common module
docs.text: The common module contains common functions and classes used by the other modules.

docs.title: hello_world()
docs.text:
Prints "Hello World!" to the console.

Source code in digitaldatai/common.py 
def hello_world():
    """Prints "Hello World!" to the console.
    """
    print("Hello World!")

docs.title: random_number()
docs.text:
Returns a random number between 0 and 1.

Returns: float: A random number between 0 and 1

Source code in digitaldatai/common.py 
def random_number() :
    """ Returns a random number between 0 and 1.

    Returns: 
    float: A random number between 0 and 1 
    """
    import random
    return random.random()

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Contributions are welcome, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given.

You can contribute in many ways:

docs.title: Report Bugs
docs.text:
Report bugs at https://github.com/azadchahal/digitaldatai/issues.

If you are reporting a bug, please include:

  • Your operating system name and version.
  • Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
  • Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.

docs.title: Fix Bugs
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with bug and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Implement Features
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with enhancement and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Write Documentation
docs.text: digitaldatai could always use more documentation, whether as part of the official digitaldatai docs, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts, articles, and such.

docs.title: Submit Feedback
docs.text:
The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at https://github.com/azadchahal/digitaldatai/issues.

If you are proposing a feature:

  • Explain in detail how it would work.
  • Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.
  • Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project, and that contributions are welcome :)

docs.title: Get Started!
docs.text:
Ready to contribute? Here's how to set up digitaldatai for local development.

  1. Fork the digitaldatai repo on GitHub.

  2. Clone your fork locally:

    $ git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/digitaldatai.git

  3. Install your local copy into a virtualenv. Assuming you have virtualenvwrapper installed, this is how you set up your fork for local development:

    $ mkvirtualenv digitaldatai
$ cd digitaldatai/
$ python setup.py develop

  4. Create a branch for local development:

    $ git checkout -b name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

    Now you can make your changes locally.

  5. When you're done making changes, check that your changes pass flake8 and the tests, including testing other Python versions with tox:

    $ flake8 digitaldatai tests
$ python setup.py test or pytest
$ tox

    To get flake8 and tox, just pip install them into your virtualenv.

  6. Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:

    $ git add .
$ git commit -m "Your detailed description of your changes."
$ git push origin name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

  7. Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:

  1. The pull request should include tests.
  2. If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the feature to the list in README.rst.
  3. The pull request should work for Python 3.8 and later, and for PyPy. Check https://github.com/azadchahal/digitaldatai/pull_requests and make sure that the tests pass for all supported Python versions.

docs.title: digitaldatai module
docs.text: Main module.

docs.title: Stable release
docs.text:
To install digitaldatai, run this command in your terminal:

pip install digitaldatai

This is the preferred method to install digitaldatai, as it will always install the most recent stable release.

If you don't have pip installed, this Python installation guide can guide you through the process.

docs.title: From sources
docs.text:
To install digitaldatai from sources, run this command in your terminal:

pip install git+https://github.com/azadchahal/digitaldatai

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
To use digitaldatai in a project:

import digitaldatai
